Co3O4 is an effective catalyst for propane total oxidation, and ZIF-67 pyrolysis is usually used to produce cobalt-based catalysts. However, high-temperature pyrolysis often leads to structural collapse and reduced cobalt activity. This study presents a CTAB-modified ZIF-67-derived hollow Co3O4-CNTs catalyst for enhanced propane total oxidation. The catalyst was synthesized through H2/Ar reduction at 800 °C and subsequent air oxidation at 300 °C. This process preserved the cubic structure of ZIF-67 and produced abundant CNTs, which limited Co3O4 growth and resulted in superior catalytic activity, with a T90 % of 230 °C-lower than that of noble metal catalysts. Increasing the oxidation temperature led to a decrease in CNTs, growth of Co3O4 particles, and structural collapse. The 300 °C calcined catalyst (300 A) showed the best performance due to its smallest Co3O4 particles and excellent reducibility, while higher temperatures led to particle agglomeration and decreased activity. Graphical Abstract Keywords VOCs Co3O4 Reduction-oxidation treatment Propane total oxidation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs), emitted from industrial processes and automobile exhaust, pose significant risks to the environment and human health due to their toxicity and volatility [1–3]. Low-temperature catalytic oxidation has emerged as the leading technology for the elimination of VOCs, offering an economical and efficient solution [4]. Propane, a stable VOC, is commonly used as a model pollutant for developing catalysts with high activity, durability, and affordability [5,6]. Transition metal oxides, such as Co₃O₄, are preferred over noble metal catalysts due to their lower cost, thermal stability, and reducibility [1,2]. Co3O4, with its spinel structure, is particularly effective for propane oxidation because of its low Co-O bond energy and unsaturated d6 and d7 orbitals [5,7]. Smaller Co3O4 particles are more effective due to their higher surface area and greater exposure of reactive species [8–10]. Advanced cobalt-based catalysts, including those with high surface area, special morphology, and dopants such as Ca, Ce, Mn, Fe, and Ni, have been developed to enhance the performance of Co3O4 [11,12]. Nowadays, the pyrolysis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has garnered widespread attention for producing efficient catalysts, owing to their well-defined, adjustable, and abundant porous structures [13–17]. Through pyrolysis, MOFs are transformed into carbon-based/nitrogen-metal composites for the catalytic combustion of VOCs [18]. Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks (ZIFs) are commonly used to synthesize efficient carbon-based cobalt catalysts due to their thermal stability. For instance, Chen et al. developed P-CNCo-20 catalysts by calcining bimetallic Zn/Co BMZIFs in an N2 atmosphere and introducing phosphorus (P) post-annealing, which exhibited excellent performance in the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [19]. Zhao et al. obtained a series of hollow Co3O4 nanoparticles by in-situ pyrolysis of ZIF-67 with varying sizes in an air atmosphere, and applied them to the catalytic oxidation of toluene to study the size-dependent effects [20]. Kong et al. prepared unique hollow Co-Ni layered double oxides (HLDO) nanocages by pyrolyzing ZIF-67 in an air atmosphere, achieving successful low-temperature catalytic oxidation of CO (T100 % = 118 °C) [21]. Qin et al. obtained Co3O4 catalysts with exceptional toluene catalytic activity by pyrolyzing ZIF-67 after tannic acid etching, with Co3O4-1–15 demonstrating the best catalytic activity (T90 % = 219 °C) [22]. Most research has focused on the pyrolysis of MOFs in either an inert or oxidizing atmosphere to prepare catalysts. However, direct high-temperature pyrolysis often leads to the collapse of the original regular structure of ZIF-67 and/or a decrease in active cobalt species, thereby reducing the activity. Different from direct pyrolysis in an inert or oxidizing atmosphere, the reduction-oxidation (RO) strategy first subjects the precursor or final material to high-temperature treatment in a reducing atmosphere, followed by treatment in an oxidizing atmosphere. This approach is beneficial for maintaining or enhancing the material's original structure [19,23], increasing particle dispersion [24], and regulating interfacial interactions [25,26], thereby boosting the material's performance in various reactions. The RO treatment of catalysts has been proven to be an effective strategy for improving the performance of the treated catalysts. Su et al. [27] discovered that RO treatment can reshape CuO, enhance its structure and surface properties, alter the Cu content, and modify the synergistic effect between copper and cerium, thereby promoting the preferential oxidation of CO. Ding et al. [24] found that RO pretreatment reduces the grain size of Co3O4 supported on Al2O3 and enhances the catalytic performance of Co3O4/Al2O3 for CO oxidation. Our team regulated the Co-Al interaction through RO pretreatment of Co3O4/γ-Al2O3, producing more active cobalt species with smaller particle sizes, which significantly improved its propane combustion activity [25]. The present research focuses on the structural and performance improvements of traditional bulk and supported catalysts in various reactions such as the oxygen evolution reaction [23], CO oxidation [24] and Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [28]. However, few studies have applied the RO strategy to the synthesis of MOF-derived catalysts through pyrolysis. Although Li et al. reported that reducing ZIF-67 at 800 °C followed by rapid oxidation at 360 °C improved the conductivity and Li+ storage in lithium-ion batteries, this improvement was attributed to the formation of carbon nanotubes and a hollow Co-Co3O4 structure during the RO treatment [29]. To the best of our knowledge, such RO-treated ZIF-derived catalysts have not been utilized in high-temperature catalytic oxidation reactions. Moreover, the detailed changes in the ZIF-67 skeleton, the Co state, the structure, and the catalytic performance of the derived Co-based catalysts after RO treatment remain unclear. Therefore, it is highly desirable to gain a fundamental understanding of the performance enhancement and structural evolution of ZIF-67 under reducing and oxidizing atmospheres at high temperatures. Herein, we primarily focused on investigating the structural evolution of ZIF-67 during reduction-oxidation (RO) treatment, which could account for their catalytic performance. A series of Co-based catalysts were obtained by pyrolyzing CTAB-modified ZIF-67, under an H2/Ar atmosphere at 800 °C, followed by calcination in air at temperatures ranging from 300 °C to 900 °C. The influences of the oxidation temperature on the structural evolution and the catalytic performance for propane oxidation were explored in detail. The results showed that the 800 °C H2/Ar reduction led to Co generation and promoted carbon nanotubes (CNTs) formation, while the subsequent oxidation in air generated hollow Co3O4 structures that were entwined by in-situ formed CNTs. The reduction-oxidation treatment effectively prevented the agglomeration of nanoparticles. The catalyst derived from 800 °C H2/Ar reduction and 300 °C air oxidation, denoted as 300 A, exhibited a uniform hollow cubic structure, smaller nanoparticles, and abundant CNTs, thus showing the best catalytic activity. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of cobalt oxide-CNTs catalysts The CTAB-ZIF-67 was firstly prepared according to the literature [29]. The dried CTAB-ZIF-67 was placed in a tube-type atmosphere furnace and was calcined at 800 °C for 2 h under a hydrogen-argon gas (5 % H2/Ar). Subsequently, the obtained product was calcined in a muffle furnace for 2 h at 300 °C, 450 °C, 600 °C and 900 °C, respectively. The catalysts obtained at these temperatures were designated as 300 A, 450 A, 600 A and 900 A. The selection of 800 °C as the pyrolysis temperature for ZIF-67 in a 5 % H2/Ar atmosphere was based on thermogravimetric (TG) analysis, which indicated that at this temperature, all Co2+ could be reduced, and the majority of the organic framework of ZIF-67 could be carbonized (Fig. S1a). The TG analysis of 800 H in air revealed a slight weight gain between 200 and 300 °C, a significant weight loss between 300 and 450 °C, and a stabilization of weight at 600 °C, followed by a sharp decrease at 900 °C (Fig. S1b). Therefore, according to the results of TG, we selected 300 °C, 450 °C, 600 °C, and 900 °C as the representative oxidation temperatures to explore the impact of oxidation temperature on the structural transformation of 800 H and to assess its catalytic performance for the total oxidation of propane. 2.2 Characterization of catalyst Thermogravimetric (TG) curves were obtained using a synchronous thermal analyzer (LINSEIS STA PT1600) under air atmosphere, with a temperature span of 30 °C to 1000 °C (10 °C /min). The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data for the samples were collected on a Rigaku D/max 2600PC instrument equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source, operating at 40 kV and 20 mA, with a wavelength (λ) of 0.15418 nm. The measurements were taken over a 2θ range from 10° to 90°. Raman spectral measurements were conducted using an Invia-reflex Laser Raman spectrometer. The instrument was excited with the 532 nm and 785 nm emission lines from an Ar ion laser. The spectral acquisition range spanned from 100 to 3200 cm−1. All Raman spectral data were essentially repeated three times to ensure reliability. The morphology of all catalysts was described using scanning electron microscope (SEM, S-4800, Hitachi) and transmission electron microscopy and high-resolution transmission electron microscope at 200 kV (TEM and HRTEM, JEOL JEM-2100F). The N2 adsorption-desorption measurement was carried out on automated gas sorption analyzer (Micromeritics ASAP 2010) at 77 K. The BET specific surface areas, the pore size distribution and pore volume of samples were obtained. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed using an Axis Ultra DLD spectrometer from Shimadzu Corporation, Japan. The XPS measurements utilized Al Kα radiation at 1486.6 eV as the excitation source and the binding energy correction for all samples were based on C1s = 284.8 eV. Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiment was performed on a Micromeritics Auto Chem II chemisorption 2920 analyzer equipped with a thermal conductive detector (TCD). 100 mg granular catalyst was obtained by pressing the tablet and placed in the quartz reaction tube (8 mm ID). H2-TPR, 100 mg of the catalyst was firstly pretreated in a He flow (30 mL/min) for 1 h at 250 °C to eliminate surface contaminants. After cooling to 50 °C, the temperature was increased to 750 °C with a rate of 10 °C /min. Then, 10 % H2/Ar mixture (30 mL/min) was flowed to pass through the catalyst to obtain H2-TPR profiles. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) were recorded using an FTIR spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Nicolet iS50) equipped with an MCT/A detector and a Harrick in situ cell. The infrared spectrum was recorded in the wavenumber 600–4000 cm−1 with 64 scans at resolution of 4 cm−1. Typically, prior to each test, the sample was pretreated under N2 flow for 30 min at 300 °C to eliminate surface water and then regulated to the target temperature to obtain a background spectrum which should be deducted from the sample spectra. Firstly, C3H8 adsorption experiment lasted for 30 mins at 50 °C under the flow of 0.1 vol% C3H8 + N2, while the oxidation of C3H8 experiment was performed at 50–300 °C in air. In addition, to further determine the reaction path of propane, high temperature adsorption in 0.1 vol% C3H8 + N2 and oxidation in air at 300 °C was conducted and the temperature-rising desorption of propane was carried out at 50–300 °C in 0.1 vol% C3H8 + Air. 2.3 Catalytic activity A continuous flow micro-reactor was used for the catalytic activity evaluation. Approximately 100 mg catalyst, sieved to a 40–60 mesh size, was placed inside a quartz tube reactor with an inner diameter of 8 mm. The reactor was fed with a gas mixture containing 0.1 vol percent of propane (C3H8) and 18 vol percent of oxygen (O2), with the balance being pure air. The mixture was introduced into the reactor at a rate of 50 mL/min, corresponding to a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 30,000 mL/(gcat·h). Temperature measurements were taken using a thermocouple positioned at the catalyst bed within the reactor. The concentration of propane in the inlet and outlet were analyzed in real-time at specified temperatures, which were held constant for 20 min, using a GC (Varian GC-450) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). Catalytic activity was evaluated over a temperature range of 50–400 °C, with conversion data being derived from the difference in propane concentrations at the reactor's inlet and outlet. For assessing the stability of the catalytic reactions, measurements were conducted under identical conditions but at a fixed temperature of 210 °C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1(a) shows the XRD patterns of CTAB-ZIF-67, 800 H and 300A-900A catalysts. The XRD pattern of CTAB-ZIF-67 matches those reported in the literature [29], indicating the successful preparation of CTAB-modified ZIF-67. After reduction at 800 °C under an H2/Ar atmosphere, the diffraction peaks belonging to ZIF-67 disappeared, and new peaks emerged at 44.3°, 51.4° and 75.8°, corresponding to the (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes of Co, respectively. This indicates that the Co2+ in ZIF-67 was successfully reduced to Co nanoparticles. Additionally, a broad peak at 21° is attributed to amorphous carbon, suggesting that the organic carbon framework was transformed into amorphous carbon after the 800 °C H2/Ar treatment. After further oxidation in air at different temperatures, six distinct diffraction peaks appeared at 19.1°, 31.3°, 36.9°, 44.8°, 59.4° and 65.3° which correspond to the (111), (220), (311), (400), (511), (440) crystal planes of Co3O4, respectively. This indicates that metallic Co was oxidized to Co3O4. Meanwhile, the peak attributed to amorphous carbon (21°) gradually diminishes, indicating a decrease in the amorphous carbon content. As the oxidation temperature increases, the characteristic peaks of Co3O4 become more intense, and the crystalline size of Co3O4 follows the order of 900 A > 600 A > 450 A > 300 A ( Table 1), suggesting that a larger amount of Co3O4 is produced or the particles size of Co3O4 gradually increases. Fig. 1(b) presents the Raman spectra of the 800 H and 300 A-900 A catalysts. In the Raman spectra of 300 A, 450 A, 600 A and 900 A, the peaks around 468 cm−1, 510 cm−1 and 671 cm−1 correspond to the characteristic vibration frequency of the Co-O-Co bond in Co3O4 [30]. Specifically, the Raman band at 671 cm−1 is attributed to the characteristic vibration frequency of the octahedral site (CoO6), which matches with the A1 g species of the crystalline Co3O4 phase. The peaks at 510 cm−1 (F2 g) and 468 cm−1 (Eg) correspond to the vibration of tetrahedral and octahedral site. Additionally, the peak near 192 cm−1 is attributed to the characteristic vibration frequency of the tetrahedral site (CoO4), which matches the symmetrical F1 2 g mode, while the weak peak at 611 cm−1 is related to the F2 2 g symmetry [31]. Furthermore, the peaks of the carbon nanotubes (CNTs) were clearly observed at 1348−1 and 1596−1 in all samples except 900 A, which correspond to the D and G peak, respectively [32]. The D peak can be attributed to the vibration of carbon atoms with dangling bonds in the disordered graphite structure, which is related to defects in the hexagonal graphite layer, while the G peak can be attributed to the in-plane vibration mode of Raman activity E2 g, which is similar to the vibration of sp2 bond in carbon atoms in a two-dimensional hexagonal lattice [33]. It is worth noting that with the increase in oxidation temperature, the peaks of Co3O4 gradually increase, while the peaks of CNTs decrease and completely disappear at 900 °C, indicating that the CNTs are oxidized [29]. Thus, the Raman results indicate that the particle size of Co3O4 increases, while the content of CNTs decreases with the increase in oxidation temperature. The morphology of a series of Co-based catalysts was investigated using field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), as shown in Fig. 2. After pyrolysis of ZIF-67 at high temperatures, the main elements of the derived 300 A-900 A catalysts are C, O and Co (Fig. S2). CTAB-ZIF-67 exhibits a unique cubic morphology with a very smooth surface, and its particle size is approximately 0.5 µm (Fig. 2a). After reduction in an H2/Ar atmosphere, 800 H retains the cubic framework of CTAB-ZIF-67 but shows slight shrinkage (Fig. 2b). The slight shrinkage may be due to the carbonization of the carbon framework. The surface becomes rough, and CNTs can be clearly seen (Fig. 2c), which is consistent with the Raman spectroscopy results. After further oxidizing 800 H in air, the obtained samples exhibited varied morphologies at 300–900 °C (Fig. 2(d-g)). The 300 A sample still maintains a cubic morphology similar to 800 H, but its surface becomes rougher, and the surface structure is very fluffy with an abundance of CNTs around it. After oxidation at 300 °C, Co0 is oxidized to Co3O4 in air, and the formed small Co3O4 particles assemble to form a surface with voids. These results indicate that the oxidation at 300 °C converts the Co0 in 800 H to Co3O4 without altering its original cubic morphology. When the temperature rises to 450 °C, the cubic morphology gradually transitions to a spherical shape, and its surface structure becomes more compact. Only a few CNTs are observed. But the framework of ZIF begins to collapse at higher oxidation temperatures, and simultaneously, Co3O4 starts to grow, which destroys the original cubic morphology and the voided surface. At the same time, the content of CNTs decreases due to oxidation at high temperatures. These phenomena are further confirmed by the morphological structures of 600 A and 900 A. As shown in Fig. 2(f-g), Co3O4 gradually grow into larger particles and no longer exhibits a relatively uniform spherical particle morphology. The void gaps on its surface are almost invisible. CNTs gradually disappear in 600 A, and no CNTs can be observed in 900 A. All these observations are in accordance with the Raman results. Fig. 3 presents the TEM and HRTEM images of the prepared samples. The TEM images of 800 H show spherical particles and CNTs structures (Fig. 3(a-b)). After oxidation at 300 °C in air, the TEM images of 300 A reveal a clear cubic structure (Fig. 3d). Additionally, many hollow nanostructures appear on the spherical particles due to the Kirkendall effect [34], and CNTs are still present (Fig. 3(d-e) and Fig. S3(a-b)). The HRTEM images of 800 H (Fig. 3c) show lattice spacings of 0.204 nm and 0.333 nm, which are attributed to the (111) crystal plane of Co (JCPDS NO. 15–0806) and the (002) crystal plane of CNTs, respectively. The HRTEM images of 300 A show lattice spacings of 0.465 nm, 0.245 nm, 0.203 nm, and 0.285 nm, corresponding to the (111), (311), (400), and (220) crystal planes of Co3O4 (JCPDS NO. 43–1003), and a spacing of 0.333 nm ascribed to CNTs (Fig. 3 f and Fig. S3c). Therefore, the HRTEM images of 800 H and 300 A demonstrate that Co or Co3O4 is entwined by CNTs. These results indicate that Co is oxidized to hollow Co3O4 after oxidation at 300 °C, and 300 A is a composite consisting of Co3O4 and CNTs. As the oxidation temperature increases to 450 °C and 600 °C, as shown in Fig. 3(g-h), the Co3O4 particle size gradually increases. When the oxidation temperature reaches 900 °C, significant agglomeration of Co3O4 particles occurs (Fig. 3i). The TEM/HRTEM results are consistent with the finding from Raman and SEM analyses. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and the BJH pore size distribution are shown in Fig. 4. Their BET specific surface areas, average pore volumes and pore diameters are listed in Table 1. Except for 900 A, the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of 300 A, 450 A and 600 A correspond to type IV isotherm with H3 hysteresis loop (Fig. 4a), and they all exhibit wide pore size distributions (Fig. 4b), indicating their irregular pore structures. According to Fig. 4, 900 A has almost no pores. It is worth noting that the pore size distribution of 450 A and 600 A are more symmetrical than that of 300 A, especially for 450 A, but 300 A exhibits a smaller average pore diameter than 450 A and 600 A (Table 1). Their pore sizes are 8.65 nm for 300 A, 12.9 nm for 450 A and 24.0 nm for 600 A, respectively (Table 1). This is probably because, on one hand, more CNTs contribute to the pore structure of 300 A compared to 450 A and 600 A. On the other hand, 300 A has much smaller particle sizes, which assemble to form the pores, and the hollow structure contributes to its small pore size. At 450 °C, the skeleton structure of ZIF is completely carbonized, forming Co3O4 particles with uniform particle distribution, which makes the pore size distribution relatively uniform and symmetrical. At 600 °C, Co3O4 particles begin to aggregate and grow, which leads to the poor symmetry of the curve of 600 A compared to that of 450 A. The richer and smaller pore size makes 300 A show the largest specific surface area (106 m2/g) and pore volume (0.25 cm3/g), followed by 450 A (56 m2/g and 0.19 cm3/g) because of its relatively uniform particle size and 600 A (20 m2/g and 0.12 cm3/g). 900 A, which has almost no pores, only shows a specific surface area of 10 m2/g and a pore volume of 0.04 cm3/g. The XPS analysis of the Co 2p and O 1 s spectra for the samples was conducted to discern the chemical states of the elements and the types of surface oxygen species, as depicted in Fig. 4(c-d). Characteristic peaks attributed to Co3O4 were observed in all samples' XPS spectra. Specifically, peaks at 780.3 eV and 795.2 eV, along with a satellite peak at 788.0 eV, are associated with the Co3+ species. Meanwhile, peaks at 781.4–781.6 eV and 796.7 eV, accompanied by a satellite peak at 802.9 eV, are indicative of Co2+ species [35]. The 300A-600A catalysts exhibit the similar Co3+/Co2+ ratio (0.47–0.50), but the ratio sharply increases to 0.79 for the 900 A catalyst (Table 1), signifying a reduction in the relative content of Co2+ at a much higher temperature. The O 1 s XPS spectrum of catalysts 300 A-900 A (Fig. 4d) reveals three distinct peaks. The peaks at binding energies of 529.7 eV, 531.1 eV, and 533.2 eV correspond to surface lattice oxygen (Olatt), surface oxygen species related to defects or low coordination (Osur), and adsorbed oxygen (Oads) from surface hydroxyl groups or adsorbed water species, respectively [35]. The Osur/Olatt ratio (Table 1), which reflects the relative amount of oxygen vacancies on the surface, decreases with an increase in oxidation temperature. The XPS data indicate that lower oxidation temperatures (300–600 °C) favor the production of Co2+ and oxygen vacancies, while higher temperatures promote the formation of Co3+ and a more perfect crystal structure. It has been documented that the activation of VOCs typically takes place on Co2+ sites, and oxygen vacancies facilitate the adsorption and activation of oxygen [36], both of which are beneficial to the propane oxidation reaction. In other words, lower temperatures enhance the formation of an active catalyst with a rich presence of active Co2+ and surface-active oxygen species. Therefore, samples 300 A-600 A, which have a higher content of surface Co2+ and active oxygen species than 900 A, are likely to demonstrate superior catalytic performance. Fig. 5 presents the H2-TPR profiles of 300A-900A catalysts. Since carbon does not reduce in this temperature range, the reduction peaks in the figure are all attributed to cobalt oxide. Except for 900 A, the samples exhibit two distinct reduction peaks below 450 °C, corresponding to the two-step reduction of Co3O4, Co3+→Co2+ and Co2+→Co [25]. Additionally, 300 A shows a broad peak at 507 °C, which is due to the methanation of carbon nanotubes after 500 °C [37]. The 900 A exhibits a single-step reduction process, which is different from that of 300A-600A, because of its large particle size of Co3O4 [38,39]. As the oxidation temperature increases from 300 °C to 600 °C, the reduction peak temperature of the sample gradually moves to higher temperatures. This is because the Co3O4 particles gradually become larger. Due to the hydrogen spillover [38,39], the H2-TPR curve of 900 A moves to a lower temperature. It is worth noting that the reduction peak temperature of 300 A is 84 °C lower than that of 450 A, and the initial reduction temperature of 300 A (201 °C) is significantly lower than that of 450 A (258 °C) and 600 A (300 °C). This is attributed to 300 A (11 nm) having smaller Co3O4 particles and containing CNTs, which improve the dispersion of Co3O4. However, as the temperature increases, Co3O4 particles agglomerate, the particle size becomes larger, and CNTs gradually decrease or even disappear, which is consistent with Raman and TEM results. 3.2 Catalyst performance Fig. 6(a) illustrates the catalytic performance of the 300A-900A catalysts in the total oxidation of propane. The main reaction product for all catalysts was CO2. The intrinsic reaction rates (r, normalized by the BET specific surface area) were also calculated to assess their intrinsic activities at 164 °C when the propane conversion was less than 20 % and are presented in Table 2. As depicted in Fig. 6(a) and Table 2, the propane conversion rate increases with the rise in reaction temperature. Conversely, the reaction activity gradually decreases with the increase in oxidation temperature, following the order of 300 A > 450 A > 600 A > 900 A (Fig. 6a), which is consistent with their intrinsic activities (Table 2). Notably, the 300 A catalyst demonstrated the highest catalytic performance. It exhibits much higher activity than the single Co3O4 and supported Co3O4 catalysts reported before [40–42], and even outperforms noble metal catalysts (Pt/Nb2O5, Pd@IM-S-1) [43,44] ( Table 3). To examine the catalytic stability of 300 A for propane oxidation, the 100 h on-stream reaction experiment was conducted at a high level of propane at 220 °C, with the result shown in Fig. 6(b). After 5 h of reaction, the conversion rate of propane significantly increased from 85 % to 97.5 % and remained stable for the following 10 h. Then, the conversion rate experienced a slight decline, fluctuating around 95 %, and finally stabilized at 95 %, showing no change for at least 40 h. The presence of CNTs restricts the growth of Co3O4, leading to smaller Co3O4 particle sizes, which promotes enhanced activity. Long-term stability tests indicate that the catalytic performance of 300 A in propane combustion can be further enhanced and it also exhibits good durability. To further investigate the intrinsic catalytic activity of the samples, we calculated the apparent activation energy (assuming no obvious change in reactant concentration within 20 % conversion rate) for propane oxidation using the Arrhenius plot (Ea) for the 300A-900A samples (as shown in Fig. 6c and Table 2). It was found that 300 A-600 A have similar apparent activation energy (Ea=82–92 kJ/mol), while the activation energy for 900 A significantly increases (Ea=135 kJ/mol), indicating that 300 A-600 A possess the same activation capability for propane total oxidation. According to the XPS results, they have similar ratios of Co3+/Co2+, suggesting that the active centers of 300 A-600 A are similar. However, 300 A (0.68 μmol/(m2⋅s) exhibits greater intrinsic activity than 450 A (0.48 μmol/(m2⋅s)) and 600 A (0.24 μmol/(m2⋅s)). Integrating the above characterization results, the excellent performance of 300 A is attributed to its smaller particle size and abundant CNTs, which result in a larger BET specific surface area. The particle size of 300 A (11 nm) is significantly smaller than that of 450 A (19 nm) and 600 A (28 nm) (XRD). 300 A retains the original cubic structure of ZIF-67, which limits the growth of Co3O4 (SEM and TEM). However, with the increase of temperature, the cubic morphology gradually transitions to a spherical shape. 450 A and 600 A still grows relatively evenly, but 900 A exhibits significant agglomeration of Co3O4 particles. This results in a rapid increase in particle size with temperature, with 900 A (66 nm) being 55 nm larger than 300 A. In addition, 300 A contains abundant CNTs, which expand its specific surface area (106 m2/g) and enhance the dispersion of Co3O4 (Raman and BET). The abundant CNTs also restricts the growth and agglomeration of Co3O4 particles. This is mainly because that the high aspect ratio and entangled network structure of CNTs physically isolate the Co3O4 particles, preventing particle-to-particle contact and Ostwald ripening. Furthermore, we plotted the relationship between the intrinsic rates of the catalysts at 164 °C and their initial reduction temperatures as well as the Osur/Olatt ratio, as shown in Fig. 6(d). The results reveal a strong correlation between the intrinsic activities and the initial reduction temperatures as well as the Osur/Olatt ratio for all samples. 300 A exhibits the best redox performance and most abundant oxygen vacancy, which is attributed to its small Co3O4 particles and higher dispersion. 3.3 The reaction mechanism over 300 A In-situ DRIFTS exploration experiments were further carried out to provide possible reaction pathways. As shown in Fig. 7(a), when a feed gas of 0.1 vol% C3H8 + N2 was adsorbed on 300 A at 50 °C for 30 mins, it was found that only the vibration peak of propane (2964 and 2876 cm−1) was enhanced, reaching adsorption saturation after 5 mins [45–47], indicating that propane can be effectively adsorbed on the catalyst surface at 50 °C. No intermediates were observed (Fig. S4a), indicating that almost no propane was oxidized during the low-temperature adsorption process. Furthermore, we introduced air to the feed gas. It is found that from Fig. 7(b-c) that, as the temperature increased, the characteristic peak of C3H8 (2964 and 2876 cm−1) weakened and disappeared at 150 °C (Fig. 7b), indicating that C3H8 can be oxidized at 150 °C, which is consistent with the activity test results. At the same time, new adsorption peaks attributed to νₐₛ(CO) of acetone and aliphatic ester (1700 and 1751 cm) and νₐₛ(COO)of acetate species (1463, 1511 and 1548 cm−1) [44,48–50] began to appear at 150 °C and strengthened first and then weakened until disappeared finally. Then, the adsorption band at 1650 cm−1 belonging to νₐₛ(OCO) of bicarbonate species were significantly enhanced and disappeared at 300 °C [44,47], showing that bicarbonate is the last intermediate in propane oxidation process. In order to better understand the mechanism of propane oxidation, high temperature adsorption in 0.1 vol% C3H8 + N2 and oxidation in air at 300 °C for 30 mins was conducted with results shown in Fig. S4b-e. The adsorption of propane reached saturation in 10 min at 300 °C. After introducing air, the desorption is complete in 5 min. During the process of propane adsorption, the vibration peaks of acetone and acetate have already appeared, which shows that propane reacts with lattice oxygen on the catalyst surface. It means that the mechanism of propane total oxidation over Co3O4-CNTs follows the Mars-van Krevelen (MVK) pathway. Further, real-time monitoring of temperature-programmed oxidation of propane with the temperature rising from 50 °C to 300 °C using a feed gas of 0.1 vol% C3H8 + Air (Fig. S4f-g) confirms the adsorption behavior and reaction process similar to that shown in Fig. 7(a). As the temperature increases, the absorption bands at 2800–3000 cm−1, characteristics of propane, gradually weaken, while the peaks at 1300–1800 cm−1, attributed to acetone, aliphatic ester, acetate and bicarbonate species, increase first and then weakened [51]. Additionally, the in-situ DFIFTs test on the samples 450 A and 600 A were also carried out, and the results were shown in Fig. S5 and Fig. S6. They all showed the similar adsorption behaviors as sample 300 A. The difference is that higher temperatures are required on 450 A and 600 A to convert propane into intermediate products and achieve complete conversion. Based on the above results, the proposed reaction pathway for propane oxidation over the 300 A (as an example) is illustrated in Fig. 7(d). Gaseous propane is firstly adsorbed onto the catalyst surface at low temperatures, forming activated propane. As the temperature rises, propane undergoes partial oxidation on the catalyst surface to produce acetone and aliphatic ester. With further increase in temperature, surface oxygen species react with the adsorbed intermediates, leading to further oxidation of acetone to form acetate and bicarbonate. Finally, all intermediates are completely oxidized to CO2 and H2O. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a series of cobalt-based catalysts derived from ZIF-67 were synthesized via pyrolysis under reducing and oxidizing conditions (RO treatment). The structural changes of the catalysts with increasing oxidation temperature and their performance in propane total oxidation were studied. Reduction at 800 °C in an H2/Ar atmosphere facilitated the formation of CNTs, while oxidation at 300 °C in air led to the creation of hollow Co3O4 entwined by CNTs. As the oxidation temperature rose from 300 °C to 900 °C, the catalysts' morphology transitioned from cubic to spherical, with corresponding increases in particle size. The 300 °C-treated catalyst (300 A) maintained ZIF-67's cubic structure and was rich in CNTs, resulting in hollow Co3O4 nanoparticles measuring just 11 nm with a large specific surface area of 106 m²/g, which contributes to its excellent catalytic activity in propane oxidation. 300 A achieved a 90 % propane conversion rate at 230 °C, significantly lower than that of reported noble metal catalysts. In contrast, catalysts treated at higher temperatures (450 A-900 A) experienced structural collapse, with a decrease in CNTs and a substantial increase in particle size, leading to reduced activity. The particle size and reducibility, influenced by CNTs and the cubic structure, are crucial determinants of catalytic performance. CRediT authorship contribution statement Hu Xiaojun: Resources. coredata.dc:description: Co3O4 is an effective catalyst for propane total oxidation, and ZIF-67 pyrolysis is usually used to produce cobalt-based catalysts. However, high-temperature pyrolysis often leads to structural collapse and reduced cobalt activity. This study presents a CTAB-modified ZIF-67-derived hollow Co3O4-CNTs catalyst for enhanced propane total oxidation. The catalyst was synthesized through H2/Ar reduction at 800 °C and subsequent air oxidation at 300 °C. This process preserved the cubic structure of ZIF-67 and produced abundant CNTs, which limited Co3O4 growth and resulted in superior catalytic activity, with a T90 % of 230 °C-lower than that of noble metal catalysts. Increasing the oxidation temperature led to a decrease in CNTs, growth of Co3O4 particles, and structural collapse. The 300 °C calcined catalyst (300 A) showed the best performance due to its smallest Co3O4 particles and excellent reducibility, while higher temperatures led to particle agglomeration and decreased activity.
coredata.dc:title: Enhancing propane oxidation with CTAB-modified ZIF-67-derived hollow Co3O4-CNTs catalysts through reduction-oxidation treatment
